reviewText:
It's like watching a Disney movie, but now you get to play through it instead

Game overview
*Genre (tags): 2d platformer, action, atmospheric
*Avg length: ~8 hours
*Developer: Moon Studios
*Publisher: Microsoft Studios
*Release date: March 11th 2015 (original), April 27th 2016 (definitive)
*Platform: pc, Xbox 360, Xbox One

<<<Pros & cons>>>

+ Excellent gameplay
+ Purchasable abilities (level up system)
+ Regular introduction of new skills and game mechanics
+ lots of exploration and secrets
+ Great atmosphere
+ Difficulties available (definitive edition)
+ Backtracking made easier (definitive edition)
+ Very tight controls
+ Visually stunning
+ Fitting soundtrack to glue everything together
+ Leaderboards
- Keys/buttons can (currently) only be rebound externally

Full game review
Ah, another Metroidvania title. You know, the type of game where you do a lot of jumping and fighting, unlock abilities and explore a vast (and often coherent) map full of adventure and secrets. Ori and the Blind Forest is, besides being well executed gameplay-wise, not just simply a copy of other titles within the genre. Due to its mind-blowing visuals, amazing soundtrack and great narrative, it offers an experience not easily forgotten. It is most likely one of the most memorable 2d platformers you'll be playing through in recent years (to come).

<<<Story>>>

On that fateful night ... Following a fierce storm, Ori, a cute little creature connected to the Spirit Tree in the forest of Nibel, is separated from its roots (...). Naru, another strange creature, finds her and cares for her as if it were her own child. They are happy together and mostly pass their days playing, eating and relaxing. Unfortunately, happy stories (as we all know) are bound to end. As the Spirit Tree desperately calls out to Ori, without success, all living beings slowly start to wither and decay. Naru and Ori have a lot of difficulty to survive themselves, so the Spirit Tree shines its light on Ori one last time: this is her chance to aid the mighty Tree and restore the balance in the forest.

<<<Gameplay, fun factor and replayability>>>

Ori is an exciting action-platformer that has excellent gameplay: from (wall)jumping, to combat to unlocking new skills and more; the game sure knows how to hit those sweet spots. Whilst playing, you'll also 'level up' regularly, which essentially allows you to spend points in the ability tree. There are 3 branches within this 'tree' that focus on certain/different aspects of the game: the offensive branch, the survival branch and the exploration branch. Whichever abilities you pick highly depend on how you want to play the game. They are not at all mandatory to be able to finish the game, however they certainly do enhance an already great experience and make life that little easier. Not only that, it also gives a sense of progression and rewards you for killing enemies instead of just skipping them.

Besides the purchasable abilities, the game also regularly offers new skills. You know, the ones that you use to explore areas that you couldn't reach yet or to do things that you couldn't do before. These skills range from the simple double jump, to reverting enemy projectiles and others. There are a total of 11 to unlock, which is honestly more than expected. You'll need those skills though, as the game also regularly throws new mechanics your way. This keeps the overall experience fresh throughout the whole adventure: once you seem to have mastered one skill, the game is eager to teach you a new one, which secures a great pacing of 'freshness'.

The main campaign is 'only' about 8 hours long (depending on how fast you are), but luckily there is some replayability to be found. One can gain some extra playable hours by exploring all of Nibel and looking for every possible secret. In the definitive edition, backtracking is also made easier by being able to teleport using spirit wells, which is another great new feature. When you are done with the main game, have everything at 100%, but still want to keep playing, you could try and take on the ultimate challenge: the so called 'one life mode', which allows you to test your skills and will track how far you've gotten via leaderbords (not recommended for the easily frustrated).

The game is extremely fun to play through, and that is because it does something really well. And that 'something' is the following: its ability to combine gameplay, visuals, soundtrack and narrative in such a way that is just exceptional. You might even forget what exactly you are playing through now and then as this is not just your average action-platformer. It is a game that'll suck you up and will have you going until the very end: a true atmospheric masterpiece.

As Ori is a very cute game in both its narrative and visual style, don't be fooled: it is still a Metroidvania title and has some (very) challenging sequences in store, like having to escape an area under time pressure for example. However, something that has changed since the original edition, is that there are difficulties (easy, normal, hard, one life) available now. This is a great upgrade, as it allows for a bigger audience. Whether you're looking for a relaxing atmospheric experience or a super challenging platformer (or both); Ori has it for you.

<<<Controls, graphics and sound>>>

Let's get it over with right away: do yourself a favour and use a controller! Whilst the earlier parts of the game are very doable with m/kb, if you keep using them in the later parts of the game, you'll probably get very frustrated. And this is just not the game that you want ruined by your own frustration. That being said, controls are extremely smooth and responsive. Executing even the tiniest of actions - doing a little bunny hop on vertical walls - is very accurate.

Visually, the game is delicious 2d eye candy, with a very detailed back- and foreground.  Between all the action and adventure, you'll most likely take a little 'break' here and there to enjoy the absolutely stunning environments. Each new environment will surprise you time after time. Many eyegasms will be had. Furthermore, the animations are fluid, detailed and - honestly - even near perfect. Walking through some grass, jumping around, sliding ... Nothing feels weird or clunky. Everything is top notch!

To top it all of, there is the wonderful soundtrack that shoots the atmosphere to unlimited heights. It sounds as it has been taken directly from a Disney movie.  It is so unbelievably good that it'll take you on an emotional rollercoaster if you let it. It is the kind that will bring you to tears years after playing this gem; a true 'nostalgia pill' if you will.

<<<The verdict>>>

Ori is an amazing game that offers just that little extra to stand out between other action-platformers. It is almost a 'crime' not to play it or at least give it a go. Especially with the added difficulties in the definitive edition (alongside with some other useful added features), there is no reason to pass it up anymore. It is a game that has mastered the art of delivering an unforgettable atmospheric experience combined with some exciting action/platforming.  In short: a true gem for nearly everyone!

I don't think I've ever been emotionally involved in a game more than in Ori and the Blind Forest, and it's been a real pleasure to play it again in the Definitive Edition, the feels are still there.
This game has everything for it, from gorgeous graphics, to insanely good music and addictive gameplay with a great difficulty curve as well as clever level design, and a nice story with adorable characters.

The new features in the Definite Edition are really nice, the difficulty settings let everyone enjoy the game the way they want, teleporting made me more motivated to find all secrets, the two new zones are really fun to explore, the new music is really pleasant to listen to, and being able to come back to the Ginso Tree and Forlorn Ruins if we forgot to get some collectibles is awesome, as well as being able to keep playing on a save file even after completing the game.

I'd also like to mention how the game runs way better than the original Ori and the Blind Forest, the problem of visuals and sound not being in sync during cutscenes isn't there anymore in the Definitive Edition, and some laggy areas of the original doesn't anymore, which is perfect if you don't have a beast of a computer.

So yeah, I really love this game, and I HIGHLY recommend anyone to play it.
Unless you really have a passionate hate towards Metroidvanias, I'm pretty sure you'll love Ori and the Blind Forest: Definitive Edition.

reviewText:
An expanded version of one of the best platformers out there.

The Ori-ginal is great by itself. It has some of the most fluid, fun controls and challenges of any game I've played, and it's clear from the start that the people of Moon Studios perfectly understood what they were doing, because everything works masterfully! Simply moving around feels great, and combined with creative environments and obstacles, it adds up to a kind of platforming brilliance that you don't see very often. Despite the structure of the game, I'd argue that it's more Rayman than Metroid, though I strongly recommend it to pretty much anyone who enjoy sidescrollers. It's a game that keeps getting better with every new challenge and every new ability, most of which only enhance the platforming (the bash ability changes everything). It also has the best quicksaving system I've ever seen.

All of it is wrapped up in a fantastic presentation. The art is detailed and gorgeous, the soundtrack is dramatic and unforgettable, and both compliment each other perfectly, as well as the grand, poetic storytelling that goes all out to make the world feel gigantic and ancient. It seems like the developers only took lessons from the best of the best, and nothing feels underwhelming, cut short or left out in any way. It's all extremely polished.

It's pretty weird that this Definitive Edition isn't just an update to the original version, because now that game is just taking up space on the store and in my library. There doesn't seem to be any reason to buy it when the DE is the same thing + new levels, new abilities, difficulty settings, fast travel options and full backtracking support (although more graphical options would've been nice as well). Having beaten the old version, all these additions were very notable, very early on, and they only serve to make the game more exciting than ever.

If you like magic, fun, challenge and feeling emotions, you should pick this up. There has never been a better time to do so.

Ori lables itself a metroidvania, and unlike some other games that make that claim (Cave Story, looking at you. You aren't a metroidvania) this one really does fit the genre.

Right away you're gonna notice how god damn beautiful this game looks. It's really pretty, and the animations on Ori and some of the other characters just add to the overall amazing aesthetics. I don't think I've played a game that looks prettier than this. Sure, some games might have better graphics, but they don't look this vibrant and alive.

Okay, anyway. So I said it's a metroidvania, right? It is, but the vast majority of Ori's powers that you will gain as you go through the game are movement based powers. You're not going to find various laser beams like Samus or anything. The gameplay is designed with this in mind, and while there are enemies in the game (they're all pushovers), your real adversary is the environment.

You'll get real familiar with double jumping up walls, going from side to side avoiding spikes or fireballs, then launching yourself off of enemy projectiles with another movement skill.  They even go as far as to not have actual bosses in the game, at least like you are expecting. What function as bosses are elaborate escape sequences from various areas that will really put your platforming skills to the test.

Aside from these new powers you'll find, you can also find the standard things like items that boost your max hp or energy, or give you a free skill point. Yeah, Ori has a skill tree. Well, it's not really a tree. He has three linear paths, each with a different theme. You have to progress down each path in order, but you can hop back and forth between the three as you like. If you put your first point in the combat path, you aren't stuck with that branch only until you complete it. Protip: do the path that ups your movement abilities first. This is much more helpful than combat upgrades. Triple jump anyone? Yes please.

I'm a huge fan of this genre, when it's done right, and this is done pretty damn right. It's not quite on the level of Super Metroid, Symphony of the Night, or Axiom Verge, but it is really close.

Oh, did I mention how pretty and cute Ori is? Buy this just to look at him. He's adorable.

...is it even a he? I don't know.

Probably the best platformer on a PC ever. Not only is this game gorgeous articistically, and in particular its soundtrack, it also challenges you. Whether you're playing for 100% completion, deathless victory, stressing through a 3-hour speedrun or just hopping around for your first time, this game provides some unique challenges that flow along beautiful gameplay. This is definitely the best non-Mario platforming game, ever. Get it and play through at least once in your life.

As far as the Definitive Edition versus the Original, the Definitive Edition offers 2 new abilities which only get truly utilized in one major new area on the map. Without any spoilers, is based around a Naru-centric story which is short but sweet. It can be confusing since rather than adding new challenges in other areas of the map, tney just forced you to get the new abilities to unlock some older ones. The greatest part is that you can get back into all the areas and use waypoints to teleport. This is nice and saves time, though if you're trying to collect all the secrets, you'll still be hoofing through areas a second time when you get triple and charge jumps. It could just be me, but I noticed some lag on the water escape which I never had on the original and shouldn't ever really have. Furthermore, I noticed Steam failed to register my achievements after a while.

In summary, I loved this game so much that quite honestly I didn't mind any of the shortcomings with the Definitive Edition-specific content, But to be clear, the definitive edition doesn't really add much of anything worthwhile. If you've never played through Ori and Blind Forest, do it. It is fantastic. If you have but are wondering if the Definitive Edition is worth getting... I'd say only as an excuse to play through it again. Keep in mind, that like most platformers, replay value is limited. You can aim for achievements, but despite my love i probably won't play it again for 6 months to a year and soonest. Ori and the Blind Forest is fantastic, and plays really well on both Xbox and Steam controllers, but can be extra challenging on a keyboard thanks to the eventual use of 8 buttons/keys for different purposes. No matter what, this game is worth playing once though. And possibly obsessing over it's soundtrack afterwards. The Definitive Edition could be worth skipping, but let's all just hope we eventually get an Ori sequal at some point.

Ori and the Blind Forest Definitive Edition Review

What is it?
Ori and the Blind Forest is a 2D puzzle-solving platformer at it's heart. With an atmospheric world, fantastic gameplay, tight controls, emotional story-line, and sweeping soundtrack - it's sure to blow away many gamers. Developed by Moon Studios, Ori has back-tracking, puzzles, fast paced combat, and a story-line keeping you from putting down the game.

Similar Games?
Metroid Series (Open World and back-tracking elements)
Castlevania Series (Back-tracking elements and combat)
The Legend of Zelda Series (For story-telling and Puzzle Solving)

Plot
Ori and the Blind Forest's story-line is one of the most emotional in 2015's gaming year. With laughs, heart-aches, sadness, fear, and happiness all rolled up into one 2D game, it's one to treasure for awhile. Ori, the last light spirit must go out and return the light lost from a great tree to restore the life of a dying forest and home. Kuro, the main antagonist, keeps Ori at bay as she tries to keep the forst blind and dark. I can't say too much without spoiling the game, but one of Ori's strongest elements is it's story-line.

Gameplay & Combat
**This game is best played with a controller!**
Ori and the Blind Forest has fast paced gameplay and combat. SImilar to Super Metroid's gameplay, you will have Ori jumping around the map as you explore the giant world, Nibel. Gracefully jumping and wall climbing, Ori is a very fast and flexible character.

Fast gameplay and movement requires fast combat as-well - Ori is occompanied by Sein, the light needed to bring back life to the forest of Nibel. Sein follows Ori and discharges light that act as attacks - get near an enemy and rapidly tap the attack button and it will damage the foe. It's not just repeated tapping to defeat an enemy, you can charge up Sein, dash through enemies, and even smash into the ground as Ori. Combat is fast, satisfying, and addictive - though it's repetitive, you'll be gliding by enemies and still want to take them down.

Ori and the Blind Forest also includes a level-up system in which you pick up light orbs that act as experience points. Gather enough and you level up and get to unlock a new ability off of your skill tree. The skill tree comes in three different categories; combat, efficiency, and utility. Each unlocks a brand new ability that greatly improves (and changes) your gameplay and the way you handle enemies and the world around you.

Visuals & Sound
By far the most impressive and best qualities of this game are the Visuals and Soundtrack. The art direction and graphics put into this game are outstanding. Each area, each screen, and each dungeon" are created in such a gorgeous and creative way that will leave you awe-struck. Made with Unity

reviewText: This game is beautiful. The artwork and direction almost feels like a movie at certain points, and at no point does the game seem rushed or overly simplified in aesthetic or level design. The abilities you collect throughout the game are all used in ways that make them feel unique and add to the experience, with none of them ever feeling like they were shoehorned in for a false sense of 'new' content that is used for only a specific section. However, it doesn't really matter, either way you look at the difficulty, too hard or too easy, it doesn't distract from the strengths of the game, the way that each level seems fresh and new, the artwork and amazing soundtrack, overall a solid 10/10.

reviewText: This version takes everything that made the original Ori and the Blind Forest the best game of 2015 and takes it up to 11.  The new areas are a lot of fun, and they add even more to the already sad/tragic story.  This game finally dethrones Super Metroid as the best 2D Metroidvania game. All in all, this makes an already amazing game even better, and I can't recommend it enough.  I think this game is worth easily double what they are asking for it, and it already has my vote for GOTY 2016.

reviewText:
I love Ori and the Blind Forest. The art is beautiful, the music is charming and enjoyable and the gameplay is fun. The definitive edition makes some good steps forward, removing all the points of no return that existed in the original, and even added the unnecessary ability to teleport between spirit wells.

If you're new to Ori, then I can't recommend picking this up enough. It's fantastic and more than worth the investment. I personally recommend starting with the original, as I feel it paces itself better and is all around a more enjoyable experience despite the points of no return.

If you're a prior owner of Ori, I would say that the new content is probably worth $5 for most of you, though I can definitely understand why some people would be disappointed. There are 2 new abilities for Ori (ignoring the passive skill tree), 1 new environment where you learn about Naru's past, and the above mentioned spirit well teleport and removal of points of no return. It's not insignificant, but perhaps not as much as the description might lead you to believe.

Highly recommended if you've never played, hesitant recommendation for prior owners until the discount expires.

reviewText:
Ori and the Blind Forest is a wonderful game. An INCREDIBLE game, in almost every way. Satisfying, enjoyable, astounding, dazzling in both graphics, style, gameplay, story and even music, it's no wonder Moon Studios has won so many awards for their beautiful game.

There are several ways you could describe Ori, if you'd dare. You could call it awesome. You could call it unbelievable. Some might call it frustrating. What ever you may call it, it deserves all the recognition it gets.

Put into the role of an orphaned Guardian Spirit, you must face the merciless and fateful forest of Nibel in its terrifying blindness, to which you must restore the weakened light to. A series of unfortunate events prior to the forest's decay sets Ori on a dangerous path, causing the Spirit Tree, the reason to all Nibel's life, to lose his power. With the guidance of the mystical creature Sein and the bravery to outmaneuver the antagonist Kuro, Ori is Nibel's last hope, a hope that must shine above all else, or the world will never live again.

What I've given you is a mere taste of this inspiring tale of hope and self-discovery; the longer version is something you will have to find for yourself. It probably has one of the best plots I have ever come across in a video game especially, and it only continues to compliment every other attribute of Ori and the Blind Forest. I found the story to be bittersweet, filled with action, thought-provoking, and beautiful in more than one way.

The artwork in Ori and the Blind Forest is altogether breathtaking. I knew, as soon as I saw it, I wanted to immerse myself in the world this game presented. And when once I did... well, let's just say it took forever to get myself out of it. The painted style of Ori and the Blind Forest is something I rarely see in such games, or if I have, it isn't executed nearly as well. The graphics in this game are what initially sold it for me, and as I played, they just complimented everything else even more.

However, Ori isn't just a pretty face- that is important in many cases, but what I'm about to talk about is the GAMEPLAY. Oh, my gosh. Where do I even begin? The mechanics in this game are genius, especially with such a spry and lithe being such as Ori. Everything from the jumps, to the dashing, to the wall climb... they are all fluid, just meant for Ori's agile form. It never once felt too slow or too laggy, and none of the mechanics felt out of place (even the newer ones, which I thoroughly enjoyed).

Am I done? NOPE. There is more still, and that is the MUSIC. The score in this game has enchanted me for the longest time. Sometimes, I'll just put my controller down, slap on my headset and listen for minutes at a time. The effort Moon Studios put into making the music a fantastical experience clearly showed in this fantastic score. The music could go from soft, to loud, to tense, to sad, all with excellent transitions. The music always felt right, and that's the best anybody can do.

I've played the original Ori and the Blind Forest before the Definitive Edition was released, but I will also be reviewing the DE as well. I loved every second of Ori and the Blind Forest, and hearing about the expansion made me buzz with excitement. The thought of returning to the world I loved so much, with even more content and artwork, was like a dream come true. After playing it through again with the DE installed, I realized I had almost forgotten how incredible this game really is. The additional areas and the added backstory with Naru made me appreciate her character perhaps even more so than I did before, and I loved leaping and flipping through the newly painted areas.

The areas, nor the added story, nor the new mechanics seemed out of place to me. That was one of my main concerns when I started playing, that it wouldn't fit with the overall game and dampen my opinion on it. But no, this was not the case even a little. In fact, I think it made me appreciate it MORE.

I'd like to mention quickly that there are a few small things; when I played Ori originally, I would encounter a few bugs, and I have found some here and there in the DE as well. But they haven't really changed anything for me; I understand that a game isn't without its few imperfections. There will be bugs.

So, am I recommending this game to you? YES. YA. SI. If you haven't noticed already, I have a high opinion of Ori and the Blind Forest. 9.8/10, I believe should be fitting. Thank you, Moon Studios, for sharing this incredible creation with us. And thank you, person reading this review, for clicking Add to Cart". ^^

The Definitive Edition is exactly what I needed to get back into this game. It still remains one of the few games I can almost always go back to and get lost in. Absolutely beautiful, remarkably fun, and the new content is definitely worth the additional $5 for anyone wondering if they should upgrade.

For folks new to the game, unless this kind of game is a complete and total turnoff to you, there's next to absolutely no reason not to experience it. Especially for the ridiculously fair price they're asking for. Don't wait for it to go on sale, support this amazing piece of work at face value. It's a purchase you wont regret, I can assure you.

One of the defining factors behind what makes the game so fun is the level of trust it has in you to grasp concepts and quickly. You'll very quickly be given new abilities which rapidly ramp up how quickly and creatively you can navigate the world, but the game is fully aware of your new capabilities and almost instantly puts them to the test. reviewText:
This game is quite literally a work of art. It's beautiful to look at, it's invigorating to play, and I guarantee you it will be one of the best - if not THE best - platformers you'll ever play with a heart warming story to boot.

The jumps in this game just FEEL right. The air time feels good, and can be slightly controlled by how long you hold the jump button. The travel distance in each jump also feels accurate and fair, and even though some of the levels will take time to adjust to you can look at the scene and just tell what needs to be done most of the time, it just takes timing.

Abilities, and the ability tree also are interesting and fun. I'd like to talk about them more but I don't want to spoil anything, but I will say that one in particular was extremely satisfying to use throughout the entire game. The ability tree feels impactful, but not so much that you feel like you miss out by going down one path too much, plus exp points can kind of be farmed if you really want every thing unlocked.

Pacing of this game did feel like it sped up a bit much at times, like it would be fairly casual going through a level with a bit of tension on landing on certain platforms and then all of a sudden there's just a rushing, climactic moment that occurs, but it luckily saves the game before each of these scenes so all is good. For the most part you can easily predict when the speed-run moments are about to occur, and with a little preperation -and a few retries for me- your gold.

The story is what really keeps you playing though. The stunning drawn backgrounds, sprites, effects, sounds, and characters on top of the gameplay will make you WANT to get through this game so badly to see what happens next, and it definitely has replay value if only to relive those warm moments. I can definitely see now why this was deemed a new classic"."

reviewText:
The Definitive Edition makes an already great game even greater!

With the Definitive Edition, 2 brand new areas are added to the game, with 2 new abilities to go along with them. Each new area makes use of the new ability and teaches you how to use them. The new Dash skill will also change the speedrun game in its entirety, allowing Ori to speed through areas once this skill is mastered. Players can also now warp between the save point wells.

For those of you having trouble with the original game, the DE adds a brand new easy difficulty. Enemies will fall over and merely tickle you, and checkpoints will be added to some of the escapes. Those of you seeking a challenge can try the new Hard difficulty, where enemies will takes less damage and kill you in 2-3 hits no matter how much health you have, and the brand new One Life mode. As the name implies, you get one life to beat the game.

Finally, there is a new story element to the game! With the addition of two new areas, players gain a bit of insight into Naru's past.

Those of you femiliar with the original version of the game will notice that althought many of the secrets remain the same, the way to access them has change. Areas that previously required the Ground Pound may now require a different ability to access them, so things have changed for even those who think they know everything just because they completed the original.

If you have the original, there's plenty new to justify the $5 purchase! If you haven't played the original, well, now you can play a superior version of Ori!

For those who haven't played the original, you may want to look at more-developed reviews on that store page.

For those who played and liked the original, the DE functions as an add-on to the original as you would expect.
The primary changes in decreasing order of priority for me are:
- 2 new movement abilities
- Two new areas
- Spirit Portals now functions as waypoint for easier backtracking (much less tedious to get 100%)
- Naru's Story
- Difficulty modes (Easy mode is very important for introducing friends to the game)
- Slight changes to ability gates in the (places you can't get past without the right ability unlocked)

The selling point for me this game are the two new abilities - Dash and Light Burst. Both have their uses in attacking and movement, giving you new ways to traverse through the old environments faster and with more grace. Fludity in movement and animations is what Ori excels in compared to any other game I have played, and adding more functional movement options sets it even apart.

Props to the devs for successfully improving what was already great.

This isn't an appraisal of the game for new players (it's very good, get it now) but me sharing my 2 cents with those who have already finished the original and are wondering if the new content justifies another purchase...
The new levels (with the new abilities) are accessible early, but do require some later abilities to complete. It's also possible to finish the game without seeing the new content, which is what I initially did. This actually frustrated me, because the only changes I initially saw involved blocking off originally accessible areas with walls that can only be opened using the new abilities. The game now includes full backtracking so if you are like me and finish it first you can still use the same save to go back and visit the new levels. They are actually really enjoyable (and very pretty), but not lengthy - I only took about an hour to see all the new stuff. New abilities are fun to use but nothing special. (bash is still by far the best!)
The new hard difficulty just makes enemies more powerful and increases environmental damage. You can now warp between spirit wells, personally I think it cheapens the game a bit as the interlocking level design is so superb.
There are some new videos/concept arts; some of the videos are fascinating, some (like the promo one with the music being recorded) are really quite uninteresting.
All in all? It's basically some glorified DLC levels, and extra goodies that *should* have been a free update. The only brilliant new stuff is the new level, and I guess the one life mode is cool. I suppose this gets a totally new release so that the original is left pure" for speedruns and whatnot

First for those who are trying to decide whether to buy the orignal version of Ori or the Definitive Edition:  buy the Definitive Edition.  Both are the same game, but this version comes with two new areas to explore and two new skills to play with.

For those who have the original and are trying to decide whether to buy the Definitive Edition:  It's the same game, aside from those two afore mentioned additions, so it depends on how much you love Ori.  For me, I REALLY love Ori, and so paying the sale price of 5$ was absolutely worth it.

Ori and the Blind Forest is an excellent game with scenes that will definitely tug on your heart strings. The visuals are breathtaking, and the level designs are quite good.

It's a metroidvania with a heavy emphasis on platforming action rather than combat, although fighting enemies is still a significant part of the game as well. How does it emphasize platforming, then? The biggest example of this is that there are no boss fights, but rather boss quality platforming challenges that require quick reflexes, good timing, and will absolutely get your heart pumping! I mean this literally. After the first of these, my heart was racing at twice its resting rate.

The story is short, as is to be expected of this type of game, but the depth and emotional impact is solid. It's very rarely that I've felt an antagonist to be fully justified in everything they have done to our hero, yet still known that I must stop them anyway.

Truly an excellent game. I highly recommmend it to you, and everyone else!

reviewText: Ori is a very fun game to anyone who's a fan of the Metroidvania style of games. From a visual standpoint it's absolutely gorgeous. The world is highly detailed and graphically impressive, with some beautiful artistic design in some areas. Most areas feel a bit bland and generic, but there is certainly a lot of variety in locations. Ori herself moves very fluidly and has a variety of moves and skills she can aquire over the course of the game, not too many, not too little. The leveling system is fair, although a majority of the points you get are just tucked away in secret areas, meaning you can get a lot of skills very early. This brings me to one of my biggest complaints, the secrets. Ori is very limited in terms of the secrets you can find, with the majority of them just being orbs that give you some points. They're also quite few and far between. Compared to other games, such as Castlevania, Metroid, Guacamelee, at least. Enemy designs I find are also lacking. I can only remember 5 enemy types. Basic enemy, dino thing, bird, orb shooter, and fish. This is part of what I mean by it feeling generic, it hits a lot of notes that many other games hit, as well as having designs that aren't very unique. But, if you just want a fun gameplay experience with beautiful visuals and fast, fluid movement, you'll like it. I certainly did.

reviewText:
After a 100% run of this game in 11.5 hours, I must say Ori and The Blind Forest: Definitive Edition is worth every penny.
Note: If you buy this game, know that you will have this version and the old version in your library. You do not need the old version to play and running the old version, at least in my case, crashes. Anyway, back to the review.

Everything to the opening cutscene to the final scene, this game is full of emotions, beautiful art style, and challenging platforming. Ori and the Blind Forest takes place within an interesting place where the darkness has taken over the light, also why it's called the Blind Forest. It is your job to repair the three elements so that you can return the light.

The game is mostly platforming but is filled with enemies along the way. You will fight many enemies and use them in interesting puzzles to make your way from location to location. But don't think it's just fighting and platforming, oh no there is more! There is an OPTIONAL skill tree that can make the game easier as you gain EXP.

But you don't only gain EXP from enemies, you can gain it through one of the three types of collectables. Yeah, there are collectables and many of them are hidden. If you want to 100% the game, you better travel to old areas where collectables weren't accessable earlier in the game. Oh but don't worry, you can use one of your skills to show collectables on the map. ;D

Finally I will take about powerups. Throughout the game, there are powerups that you gain that helps you enter areas once unreachable. You gain the ability to reach new areas, new secrets, and push further into the game. The powerups require skill but not enough to the point you have to do near impossible feats.

I will end this review with my only complaints being 1) the game is short. Short in the fact that I want MORE! The game was amazing, and I would love for a sequel. 2) There are NO epic boss fights. Yeah there is combat but it's with a miniboss you see three times and only with the small guys. But since this game is platforming, you end the game with platforming. I won't ruin the surprise, but I definitely recommend playing this all the way through.

Ori and the Blind Forest is an experience, an experience I would love to experience again. Now... Sequel please!!!

This game is one of my absolute favorites. I remember seeing the trailer before getting Steam and wanting the game. When I finally did get Steam on my computer, Ori was the first game I bought.

The art is beautiful, the music is beautiful, the story is interesting, and the gameplay is fun with just the right amount of challenge.

If you like exploration, platforming, and puzzles - this game is for you.
If you like games that are visually stunning and atmospheric - this game is for you.
If you like games with great soundtracks - this game is for you.

My favorite part of Ori is that it is so immersive. The world of Nibel is beautifully constructed and every area, though each unique, flow together really well. I really enjoyed running from one end of the map to the next to experience the music shifts and the colors switch tone.

I've spent 30 hours playing the original game and around 20 hours playing the definitive edition, and I feel like each of those hours are worth the $20 cost of the game. (Or $5 if you own the original!)

This game pulls you in, and makes you think. It can be relaxing and fun at one time and challenging and intense the next. The balance between the two is so well done. I can't reccommend this game enough. If you have any interest at all, I say take the plunge...you won't regret it!
